metadata.title: The Data Science In BTS’s ‘Map Of The Soul: 7’ | by Manasi Mahadik | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The Data Science In BTS’s ‘Map Of The Soul: 7’
metadata.description: The adjectives in Big Hit entertainment, BTS’s parent company’s name seems too paltry to describe the global mega stars that they have created. It is downright absurd to call BTS just big and hit…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: a whopping 74 individuals who are listed as either writers or producers

all_paragraphs: The adjectives in Big Hit entertainment, BTS’s parent company’s name seems too paltry to describe the global mega stars that they have created. It is downright absurd to call BTS just big and hit, legendary and groundbreaking could come close. In fact the hysteria at a BTS concert is so massive that according to the New York Times, the noise level in their concerts are "well past the noise level at which permanent hearing loss becomes a serious concern”. The band from Seoul contribute a whopping $ 4.65 billion to South Korea’s GDP, more than the national airline, a comical irony because BTS can’t actually fly Korean Air. Some sasaeng fans of the BTS ARMY (Adorable Representative MC for Youth) illegally obtained their flight details, and hounded them during flights, making it impossible for them to fly any commercial airline.

If BTS could time travel to 7 years back, at the cusp of their debut and flick a coin in a wishing well for every milestones they would go on to break, the well would well, choke. Their reality today is perhaps bigger than any dream the septet could have imagined. And at this level of intense super stardom and Midas like touch, they’ve made their comeback with thier fourth EP - ‘Map Of The Soul : 7’. In the months leading to the album release, BTS has promoted multiple singles, performed at the iconic transit hub — Grand Central Terminal in New York City for ‘The Tonight Show’, featured in a mini van for James Corden’s “Carpool Karaoke” , given multiple interviews and have done meticulously promotions both in America and South Korea. In fact, the golden maknae of the group, Jungkook even ramped up his english skills to send words of love and appreciation to his American ARMY. The album received 4 million pre-orders and upon release sat at the zenith of every chart.

The new album is tasked with acknowledging and riding on their success story but also forging the band’s road ahead in the face of unprecedented media scrutiny. It is a love story about themselves, a much deserved we made it epiphany, along with a sigh of responsibility acknowledging that they are now entering uncharted waters- where no one has gone before, with the only records to break are the ones set by themselves.

BTS primarily sing their songs in Korean and almost immediately the translated lyrics are available online for their international audiences to interpret. I tapped into the genius Web API to understand the number of annotations per song. I used the ‘GenuisR’ package in R which provides a easy interface to access the Genius web API. The API client access management page needed to make the client_id and a client_secret can be found here. Here is a small glimpse of the annotation track data-

I have used highcharter() , the R wrapper for the Highcharts JS package in order to visualize the data. You can read more about applications of highcharter() in R from one of my previous posts here. As expected, the most analyzed song is BTS’s biggest song till date- “Boy With Love (ft. Halsey)” followed by “ON (Ft. Sia)”. The next two songs are rather introspect ones, belonging to group’s rappers. J-Hope’s “Outro: Ego” which is a tribute to their journey “Life not of J-Hope but Jeong Ho-seok flashes by”, he says as the childhood pictures appear and Suga’s moving take on the struggles of fame, “Interlude : Shadow”.“Fame is like a shadow,” Suga told The Guardian just before the Korean superstars’ first UK shows in 2018. “There’s light and there’s darkness; it’s something that follows you constantly and not something you can run away from.” He carries that thought with him and makes it the central nemesis in his fiery rap album opener.

“I wanna be a rap star/I wanna be the top,” he begins in his rage engulfed sermon, blatantly laying out his ambition. But now the success the once-struggling producer longed for has well and truly been secured,it’s not as rose tinted as he imagined. “I’m afraid, flying high is terrifying,” he resigns. “No one told me how lonely it is up here.” Looping back to that idea of the titular shadow, he later raps from its perspective, warning himself: “We are one body, sometimes we will clash/You can never break me off, this you must know.” Lyrics reminiscent of Eminem’s “Almost famous” prescient warning “Be careful what you wish for”, and even the isolation and “Tragic portrait of an artist //Tortured, trapped in his own drawings” that Eminem paints in “Bad Guy”.

Each member of the group comes with a story and their own distinctive style and musical inclement calling the album to generously makes space for everyone. It is rife with solo songs and duets between members allowing them to tell their story from their own lens and leading to melange of sonic ranges and genres. “The genre is BTS”- Jungkook, J-Hope and Jin recently said. In order to classify these esoteric tides and ebbs in melodies, I classified the the 20 song EP into four buckets basis their “Energy” and “Valence” i.e musical positiveness sonic scores sourced from the Spotify Web API.

To access the Spotify application program interface, I used the interface provided by the ‘Spotifyr’ package. The Spotify web developer API access needs a unique client_id and a client_secretwhich can be made here. The ‘Spotify for Developers’ website created by Spotify is also an excellent resource for developers who are keen to use the Spotify interface. You can also link your own Spotify account and your playlist and do some nerdy analysis on what you actual listen to. You can find some wonderful use cases of integrating the Spotify web API in R here, here, here and here.
Below is a small glimpse of some of Spotify’s sonic attributes and their scores-

To create the visualization of the songs I used the wonderful ggplot2 in R, a declaratively visualization creating system, based on The Grammar of Graphics. The scatter bubbles in the chart are colored basis the sentiment they largely represent and are sized by their intensity of that sentiment.

“I think it’s less meaningful to put music into genres”, Suga once professed. With his “Interlude : Shadow” sulking at a 0.15 on the musical positivity index as compared to “Boy With Luv ft. Halsey” jumping with joy at 0.75, the group rebelliously runs free — clearly disbanding the conformities of genre definitions.

“BTS love each other so much, they don’t know what to do about it” — the editor of CREA magazine once proclaimed, after covering the group. This natural camradiere that they share gives fans something to hold on and helps keep up with their frenetic work schedule. “Friends”, a duet by V and Jimin lovingly shipped by fans as Vimin, is a tribute to their friendship — from being schoolmates and Big Hit trainees to being a part of the biggest band in music, they have indeed come a long way. “One day when this cheer dies down, stay by my side” , they make promises and like hopeful unjaded teenage lovers unbeknownst to the world ahead croon, “For eternity, keep staying here” . And with “I remember our uniforms, our memories, each and every of our movies” they pay a sweet homage to their boyhood days. The track is an antithesis to toxic masculinity and machismo and is a pleasant refreshing tale of an unabashed old school bromance.

Scoring high on both energy and valence, the most joyful track award goes to the bubblegum pop hit from “Persona”, “Boy with Luv ft. Halsey”, the current record holder for the most viewed YouTube video in 24 hours. While Jungkook’s “My time” and Jin’s “Moon”, a tributes to the fans — “you’re my earth, all I see is you”, score in the chill and peaceful bucket.

When Big Hit founder Bang PD first recruited the team’s leader and rapper, then known as Rap Monster, the intent was to create a hip-hop centric group. He switched to creating an idol group only after judging market sentiment and commercial viability, leading many of the hip-hop inclined trainees to exit the company. RM and Suga the group’s current rappers stayed resolute and loyal. Now with “MOTS : 7”, 7 years since their debut the transition into a commercially viable idol group seems complete. In order to visualize the transition of sonic elements in BTS albums, I created ridgeplots using the geom_ridgeline() function in the ‘ggridges’ package in R. I then used the “Speechiness”, “Acousticness” and “Liveness” scores for this album and juxtaposed it with their debut album — “2 Cool 4 Skool”. The web developer API defines speechiness as the presence of spoken word in a track, liveness as the probability that the song was recorded with a live audience and acousticness as the likelihood of the song to be an acoustic one. The evolution is clear. Although the MOTS:7 has a whopping 20 tracks as compared to just 9 in their debut album, the overall liveness acousticness & speechiness score is significantly lower in this album. Ringing falsettos,turbulent strings, gunshot effects, and plinking synth purge through the album, a testament to a whopping 74 individuals who are listed as either writers or producers, a head dizzyingly large number of cooks to have in the kitchen.

Most artists evolve. Even the Beatles had to transition to go from “Love me Do” to “Hey Jude”. Art is a reflection of life and as life changes so does the art that artists create. But some songs of the album lack the genuinity & authenticity that is usually expected in a BTS album, especially because they brand themselves mainly on these attributes. It seem like the company’s latest attempt for brand activation with some numbers especially crafted for their sold out stadium tours and western audiences. From building BTS themed hotels, creating cinematic documentaries to producing K-dramas based on the lives of BTS members, Big Hit seems to cash in on everything that can carry the BTS tag and some songs in this album seem to be included to do exactly that — amplified with the curse of overproduction. It’s a centuries old dilemma, Louisa May Alcott sold her heroine to marriage in “Little women” , as necessitated for book to gain commercial viability in the 1860’s, I do hope that the evolution to the modern times that we live in will allow BTS to just let their heroine be.

I actively started listening to K-Pop in 2011, 2NE1, Big Bang and Shinee ruled over the industry and it was impossible to not fall into their trap. Fast forward 9 years later, Bom of 2NE1 was accused of drug trafficking, Big Bang’s Seungri is embroiled in a prostitution scandal and Shinee’s main vocalist Jonghyun tragically succumbed to suicide last year. Even recently Chen, a member of the Exo-M has reportedly received death threats after he revealed that his previously undisclosed girlfriend and now fiancée, is pregnant, a deed many K-pop fans term absolute betrayal. The pressures of K-pop industry is intense and BTS are currently at the front line. They’re often treated like male china dolls, with their company deciding their hair color and sending security teams to accompany them to the washroom granting them no privacy even in the most basic sense. In a overly sanitized and conceited K-pop industry, V & Suga have been refreshingly candid about struggling with fame and constant privacy invasion. In the last few albums they make as a septet before they leave to serve their compulsory military service, I hope BTS’s message goes deeper and does not get filtered out in their massive entourage of producers and songwriters.

What Suga wants, Suga gets. The once struggling delivery boy in Seoul has been openly ambitious of BTS’s next move. Sell out the Olympic stadium in Korea he proclaimed when BTS had just debuted, the billboard top hot 100 when no K-pop group had ever come close, performing at the Grammys he said next, to gasps of absurdity in the room. They’ve done it all, in spectacular fashion. If rules of reverence ever existed, BTS doesn’t know them. What’s next? A Grammy award for the rebels from Seoul, Suga recently said. The Grammy’s are 9 months from now, we will have to wait and watch if this time too Suga gets what he wants.
